channel.title: NYT > World News
channel.copyright: Copyright 2019 The New York Times Company

item.title: Iran Tried to Block British Tanker in Persian Gulf, U.K. Says
item.description: Amid rising tensions in the gulf, the Iranian vessels turned away only after receiving warnings from a British Navy ship, the government said.
item.dc:creator: David D. Kirkpatrick

item.title: Life in a City Without Water: Anxious, Exhausting and Sweaty
item.description: A weak monsoon and years of draining groundwater have parched Chennai, a city of nearly five million people on the southeastern coast of India.
item.dc:creator: Somini Sengupta
item.media:credit: Rebecca Conway for The New York Times
item.media:description: Residents collecting water delivered by a tanker in the Royapettah district in Chennai, India, last month.

item.title: U.K. Parliament Workers Face Intolerable Abuse, Report Says
item.description: Employees described the conditions as deplorable, with one saying that sexual harassment was a “necessary evil” for young, ambitious staff members.
item.dc:creator: Benjamin Mueller
item.media:description: A study found that sexual harassment was considered a “necessary evil” for young, ambitious workers in the Houses of Parliament and that the atmosphere was “stressful and hostile.”

item.title: In Italy, a Decades-Long Search for a Missing Girl Brings Another Twist
item.description: Vatican officials allowed the opening of two tombs to determine whether Emanuela Orlandi, who disappeared in 1983, could be buried inside. The tombs were empty.
item.dc:creator: Elisabetta Povoledo
item.media:description: Demonstrators at the Vatican.

item.title: U.N. Rights Council to Investigate Killings in Philippine Drug War
item.description: President Rodrigo Duterte’s campaign against drug dealers and users has left thousands of people dead, and has been denounced as a lawless atrocity.
item.dc:creator: Nick Cumming-Bruce
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:description: Relatives showed pictures of victims of the antidrug campaign during a theater performance in Manila this month.

item.title: Europe Shut These Migrants Out, Then Libyan Rebels Bombed Them
item.description: A July 2 airstrike in Libya killed more than 50 migrants and refugees at a detention center. Our investigation found that they were being held less than 100 yards from a weapons depot that had been struck two months earlier.
item.dc:creator: Evan Hill
item.category: Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis

item.title: He’s Writing 365 Children’s Books in 365 Days, While Holding Down a Day Job
item.description: Matt Zurbo’s challenge, named after his daughter, Cielo, is an unconventional labor of love.
item.dc:creator: Damien Cave
item.media:credit: Peter Tarasiuk for The New York Times
item.media:description: Matt Zurbo works at an oyster farm in addition to writing children’s books. “Imagination trumps violence and ignorance, and always will,” he says.

item.title: Vincent Lambert, Frenchman at Center of Right-to-Die Case, Dies at 42
item.description: Mr. Lambert, a nurse who was left in a vegetative state after a 2008 accident, had been taken off life support. The case bitterly divided his family.
item.dc:creator: Aurelien Breeden
item.media:description: A neurologist and adviser to Vincent Lambert’s parents showing the patient’s picture in a vegetative state at the United Nations Human Rights Council in Geneva on Monday.

item.title: She Was Duped and Shipped to a Brothel at 16. Then the Boat Sank.
item.description: In April, a boat smuggling dozens of people out of Venezuela, some entrapped by a human trafficking ring, capsized in the sea on the way to Trinidad. Only nine people survived.
item.dc:creator: Nicholas Casey
item.media:credit: Adriana Loureiro Fernandez for The New York Times
item.media:description: Yoskeili Zurita, 16, was one of nine survivors of a boat that capsized as it was smuggling people from Venezuela to Trinidad.

item.title: Violent Thunderstorms Kill at Least 7 in Northern Greece
item.description: Six foreigners were said to be among the dead after intense wind and rain hit the Halkidiki region. More than 100 others were injured, officials said.
item.dc:creator: Iliana Magra
item.media:description: Damage in the village of Nea Plagia, Greece, on Thursday.

item.title: Fatal Accident With Metal Straw Highlights a Risk
item.description: The disturbing death of a woman in Britain renewed a debate that has followed bans on plastic straws around the world.
item.dc:creator: Neil Vigdor
item.media:description: Metal straws have gained popularity as cities, states and even countries have banned single-use straws.

item.title: In South Korea, Gay Soldiers Can Serve. But They Might Be Prosecuted.
item.description: Male soldiers who have consensual sex are being charged with committing “indecent acts,” even though the army says it does not discriminate against sexual minorities.
item.dc:creator: Choe Sang-Hun
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:credit: Lam Yik Fei for The New York Times
item.media:description: A soldier in Seoul, South Korea.

item.title: Merkel Is Seen Shaking Again, Renewing Health Concerns
item.description: It was the third time in less than a month that Chancellor Angela Merkel of Germany had been seen trembling, but she insisted that her health was fine.
item.dc:creator: Melissa Eddy
item.media:description: Chancellor Angela Merkel, right, and Prime Minister of Finland Antti Rinne in Berlin, on Wednesday.

item.title: U.S. Accuses Iran of ‘Nuclear Extortion’ and Vows More Sanctions
item.description: Maneuvering over the nuclear deal was punctuated by U.S. accusations of Iran extortion, French attempts to start talks and Trump’s vow of more sanctions.
item.dc:creator: Steven Erlanger
item.media:description: The American ambassador to the International Atomic Energy Agency, Jackie Wolcott, described Iran’s activities as “nuclear extortion.”

item.title: Young Afghan General Tries to Reform Police With American Way of War
item.description: Coming up through elite U.S. and British training, he is a favorite of Western commanders. But his police forces are under siege, and corruption is still a problem.
item.dc:creator: Thomas Gibbons-Neff
item.media:credit: Kiana Hayeri for The New York Times
item.media:description: General Khoshal Sadat has taken command of the Afghan police forces at a critical time on the battlefield and politically. “We’ve had bad leadership,” he said, “and I had to stop the bleeding.”

item.title: British Tanker, Parliament, Russia: Your Friday Briefing
item.description: Here’s what you need to know.
item.dc:creator: Melina Delkic

item.title: Indigenous Australians Want a ‘Voice to Parliament.’ What Does That Entail?
item.description: In 2017, Indigenous Australian leaders called for a voice to parliament to be enshrined in the constitution. Could that happen within three years?
item.dc:creator: Isabella Kwai
item.media:description: An Aboriginal flag over the Australian War Memorial in Canberra.

item.title: Ignored at Home, Battered Russian Women Take Cases to Europe
item.description: In a first, the European Court of Human Rights in Strasbourg found in favor of one woman whose pleas for help were ignored by the Russian police.
item.dc:creator: Andrew Higgins
item.media:description: A rally in Moscow in 2017 against a law that weakened domestic violence protections.

item.title: U.A.E. Pulls Most Forces From Yemen in Blow to Saudi War Effort
item.description: The major reduction in troops by the Emiratis, the military linchpin of the Saudi-led war in Yemen, is a belated recognition that the war is no longer winnable.
item.dc:creator: Declan Walsh and David D. Kirkpatrick
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces

item.title: A Koch Executive’s Harassment in China Adds to Fears Among Visitors
item.description: Amid worsening trade tensions, an American businessman was barred for days from leaving, in an apparent message to President Trump. Others worry they may be next.
item.dc:creator: Paul Mozur, Alexandra Stevenson and Edward Wong
item.media:credit: Lam Yik Fei for The New York Times
item.media:description: Business executives, other frequent visitors to China and Washington officials have expressed increasing alarm over instances in which the Chinese authorities have detained or harassed Americans.

item.title: Census, Tropical Storm Barry, ‘The Lion King’: Your Thursday Evening Briefing
item.description: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
item.dc:creator: Remy Tumin and Lisa Iaboni

item.title: General Calls Rushed Troop Withdrawal From Afghanistan a ‘Strategic Mistake’
item.description: Gen. Mark A. Milley’s comments came during his Senate confirmation hearing for chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff.
item.dc:creator: Thomas Gibbons-Neff
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:description: American soldiers last month in Wardak Province, Afghanistan.

item.title: 5 Lobster Tails and a $560 Bottle of Wine, at Taxpayers’ Expense, Give Macron a Headache
item.description: After a photo was publicized showing France’s ecology minister enjoying a lavish meal at taxpayer expense, President Emmanuel Macron was confronted with more accusations of elitism in his government.
item.dc:creator: Adam Nossiter

item.title: Trump’s Asia Gamble: Shatter Enduring Strategies on China and North Korea
item.description: Trump officials are pursuing unorthodox Asia policies that are winning more support across Washington, including from some Democrats. But the moves could deepen conflicts.
item.dc:creator: Edward Wong
item.category: Arms Control and Limitation and Disarmament
item.media:description: President Trump and North Korea’s leader, Kim Jong-un, met at the Demilitarized Zone last month.

item.title: Iran, South Korea, Chennai: Your Friday Briefing
item.description: Living without water in Chennai.
item.dc:creator: Alisha Haridasani Gupta

item.title: Archaeologists Find Rare Viking-Age Boat Burials in Sweden
item.description: One of the burials, believed to date to the 10th century, contained the remains of a man, a horse and a dog. A researcher called the graves “exceptional” and a “once in a lifetime opportunity.”
item.dc:creator: Alan Yuhas
item.media:description: The skeleton of a Viking-age man found buried in a boat in Gamla Uppsala, Sweden, on the outskirts of the city of Uppsala.

item.title: What Leonardo da Vinci Couldn’t Finish
item.description: “Saint Jerome Praying in the Wilderness” at the Met Museum is a masterpiece in progress from a perfectionist who hated to say “done.”
item.dc:creator: Holland Cotter
item.media:description: A detail of Leonardo da Vinci’s “Saint Jerome Praying in the Wilderness” at the Metropolitan Museum of Art. Unfinished, it nevertheless leaves an impression of fever-pitch devotion.

item.title: Taiwan President Risks Infuriating China With U.S. Visit
item.description: President Tsai Ing-wen of Taiwan, which China considers a breakaway province, visits the United States and the Caribbean.
item.dc:creator: Rick Gladstone
item.media:description: President Tsai Ing-wen of Taiwan arriving at a hotel in New York on Thursday.

item.title: Afghan War Casualty Report: July 5-11
item.description: At least 143 pro-government forces and 51 civilians were killed in Afghanistan during the past week.
item.dc:creator: Fahim Abed

item.title: Why Did This Extinct Bird Have Such a Weird, Long Toe?
item.description: The Cretaceous Period flier, trapped in amber 99 million years ago, had features unlike any bird living today.
item.dc:creator: Becky Ferreira
item.media:description: An artist’s reconstruction of Elektorornis chenguangi, which may have used its elongated toe to search for food.

item.title: Climbers Flock to Uluru Before a Ban, Straining a Sacred Site
item.description: A rush of visitors to the central Australia monolith ahead of an Oct. 26 deadline has brought an increase in trash, trespassing and illegal camping, officials say.
item.dc:creator: Tacey Rychter

item.title: Immigration, Jeffrey Epstein, Megan Rapinoe: Your Thursday Briefing
item.description: Here’s what you need to know.
item.dc:creator: Mike Ives

item.title: Should Neil Armstrong’s Bootprints Be on the Moon Forever?
item.description: With renewed interest in the moon, some say it’s time to consider whether, and how, to preserve humanity’s lunar heritage.
item.dc:creator: Nadia Drake

item.title: Europe Shut These Migrants Out, Libyan Rebels Bombed Them
item.description: A Times investigation shows that the African migrants killed by a July 2 airstrike in Libya were being detained near a weapons depot — a prime target in the country’s civil war. Before the attack, the E.U. ignored calls to move the migrants.
item.dc:creator: Evan Hill, Dmitriy Khavin, Christiaan Triebert, Haley Willis, Malachy Browne and David Botti
item.category: Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis
Human Rights and Human Rights Violations

item.title: British Ambassador, Epstein, Merkel: Your Thursday Briefing
item.description: Here’s what you need to know.
item.dc:creator: Melina Delkic

item.title: Iran Tried to Block British Tanker in Persian Gulf, U.K. Says
item.description: Amid rising tensions in the gulf, the Iranian vessels turned away only after receiving warnings from a British Navy ship, the government said.
item.dc:creator: David D. Kirkpatrick

item.title: Interpol Operation Seizes More Than 10,000 Animals in Anti-Trafficking Campaign
item.description: The world police agency and local authorities recovered 30 big cats, thousands of live reptiles and birds, and dolphins, sharks and other animals.
item.dc:creator: Alan Yuhas
item.category: Far East, South and Southeast Asia and Pacific Areas
item.media:description: An officer with Ecuador’s environmental police holds a snapping turtle found at a checkpoint inspection.

item.title: The Vietnam War Was Already Lost, but I Had to Go Anyway
item.description: Fifty years ago, American troops began withdrawing, but tens of thousands were yet to die.
item.dc:creator: William Broyles Jr.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces

item.title: Federal Reserve, Kim Darroch, World Cup: Your Wednesday Evening Briefing
item.description: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
item.dc:creator: Remy Tumin and Lisa Iaboni

item.title: China Rebuked by 22 Nations Over Xinjiang Repression
item.description: In an embarrassment for China, 22 countries rejected its version of events in the Xinjiang region, where a million or more people are in detention centers.
item.dc:creator: Nick Cumming-Bruce
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:description: The gate of what is officially known as a vocational skills education center in Xinjiang, in western China.

item.title: Alexa Now Gives U.K. Users N.H.S. Medical Advice
item.description: Britain’s National Health Service has collaborated with Amazon to offer health information through Alexa, prompting questions about privacy and market advantage.
item.dc:creator: Iliana Magra
item.media:credit: Chona Kasinger for The New York Times
item.media:description: Amazon devices that offer the company’s voice assistant, Alexa. In Britain, health questions will now receive answers from the National Health Service website.

item.title: Audio Suggests Secret Plan for Russians to Fund Party of Italy’s Salvini
item.description: A similar recording brought down the Austrian government this year, but Italy’s most powerful politician has deflected the flap around his nationalist party.
item.dc:creator: Jason Horowitz
item.media:description: Italian Interior Minister Matteo Salvini arrives at the League party headquarters after voting in the European Union election comes to a close, in Milan, in May.

item.title: Britain, Netflix, Hello Kitty: Your Thursday Briefing
item.description: Have U.S. trade policies worked?
item.dc:creator: Alisha Haridasani Gupta

item.title: It Looks Like a Lake Made for Instagram. It’s a Dump for Chemical Waste.
item.description: Siberians have flocked to an industrial waste pond where iridescent water resembles a tropical seascape, with the goal of taking humorous pictures.
item.dc:creator: Andrew E. Kramer

item.title: How Australia Could Almost Eradicate H.I.V. Transmissions
item.description: The most recent advance in Australia’s decades-long fight against the virus is the rapid adoption of a preventive drug regimen known as PrEP.
item.dc:creator: Livia Albeck-Ripka
item.media:credit: Christina Simons for The New York Times
item.media:description: Mark Binette, 34, a physiotherapist from Melbourne, Australia, who is on PrEP. He said people living with H.I.V. have long carried the burden of preventing its spread.

item.title: ‘It Could Have Been Any of Us’: Disdain for Trump Runs Among Ambassadors
item.description: Sir Kim Darroch, the British ambassador who resigned Wednesday, was not alone in his criticism of the Trump administration and its habit of leaving foreign envoys in the dark.
item.dc:creator: David E. Sanger
item.media:description: Sir Kim Darroch in 2017. Mr. Darroch often tried to reach out to the White House and the National Security Council, but he never quite felt that he broke into the Trump administration’s inner circle.

item.title: A Skull Bone Discovered in Greece May Alter the Story of Human Prehistory
item.description: The bone, found in a cave, is the oldest modern human fossil ever discovered in Europe. It hints that humans began leaving Africa far earlier than once thought.
item.dc:creator: Carl Zimmer
item.media:credit: Katerina Harvati, Eberhard Karls University of Tübingen
item.media:description: A reconstruction of Apidima 2, which was shown to be a Neanderthal skull. A far older skull fragment, Apidima 1, was also assumed to be Neanderthal, but scientists now say it belonged to a modern human.

item.title: Following the Money That Undermines Climate Science
item.description: Also this week, why you should talk about global warming
item.dc:creator: Tik Root, Lisa Friedman and Hiroko Tabuchi

item.title: These Companies Wanted Tariffs. How Are They Faring Now?
item.description: President Trump’s trade policies have helped American steel, aluminum, lumber, solar and washing-machine businesses, but not as much as they might have hoped.
item.dc:creator: Peter Eavis
item.media:credit: Lynsey Weatherspoon for The New York Times
item.media:description: Westervelt said it was spending $190 million to build a lumber mill in Alabama because President Trump imposed tariffs on Canadian lumber imports in 2017.

item.title: Two U.K. Hospitals Allow Vape Shops in Bid to Promote Smoking Ban
item.description: Although e-cigarettes have met with criticism in the United States, public health officials in Britain have embraced their use as effective for people who want to quit smoking.
item.dc:creator: Palko Karasz
item.media:description: A sign at University Hospital Lewisham in London in 2017. Most British hospitals have banned smoking on their grounds.

item.title: Brazil Judge Holds Mining Company Liable for Damages of Deadly Dam Breach
item.description: The ruling represented the first time the mining giant Vale has been formally held responsible for a disaster that unleashed a wave of toxic mud and killed at least 247 people.
item.dc:creator: Ernesto Londoño
item.media:description: Emergency crews in May using an amphibious vehicle and heavy machinery to search for bodies in the mud, 99 days after the collapse of the dam in Brumadinho, Minas Gerais State, Brazil.

item.title: Reporters Without Borders Urges Saudi Arabia to Free 30 Jailed Journalists
item.description: The press freedom group met with the Saudi foreign minister and justice minister this year, in a visit spurred by outrage over the killing of Jamal Khashoggi.
item.dc:creator: Megan Specia
item.media:description: A protest outside the Saudi embassy in London in October over the killing of the dissident writer Jamal Khashoggi.

item.title: Kim Darroch, U.K. Ambassador, Resigns After Leak of Trump Memos
item.description: Mr. Darroch said he could no longer perform his role after the leak of his memos calling the Trump administration “clumsy and inept” and President Trump’s angry reaction.
item.dc:creator: Stephen Castle
item.media:description: Kim Darroch, the British Ambassador to the United States, in Washington in 2017.

item.title: Australia Will Hold Referendum on Indigenous Recognition
item.description: Some Indigenous leaders said they were glad that the government had finally promised to hold a referendum after years of false starts, but they were wary of the governing party’s lack of details.
item.dc:creator: Livia Albeck-Ripka
item.media:description: Ken Wyatt, minister for Indigenous Australians, said the government would not hold the referendum if it appeared it would not pass.

item.title: Seeking Revenge, Taliban Target Afghan Soldiers’ Families
item.description: In one shocking case, a sergeant sent his wife and son to the wedding of his nephew — a Taliban infiltrator, who killed them.
item.dc:creator: David Zucchino and Farooq Jan Mangal
item.media:description: Soldiers in Afghanistan, as well as police officers, have seen family members killed in a series of retaliatory attacks by the Taliban.

item.title: Iraqi Refugee Is Convicted in Germany of Raping and Murdering Teenage Girl
item.description: The man was sentenced to life in prison for killing the 14-year-old in a case that fueled outrage, particularly on the far right, at the handling of asylum seekers.
item.dc:creator: Melissa Eddy
item.category: Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis
item.media:description: Ali Bashar obscured his face in court in Wiesbaden, Germany, on Wednesday. He was sentenced to life in prison.

item.title: Alexander Acosta, Twitter, Rip Torn: Your Wednesday Briefing
item.description: Here’s what you need to know.
item.dc:creator: Mike Ives

item.title: Papua New Guinea Massacre Kills Pregnant Women and Children, Police Say
item.description: At least 20 people were killed in an ambush and retaliatory massacre among rival communities.
item.dc:creator: Isabella Kwai
item.media:credit: Philip Pimua/Department of Health, via Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Remains of people killed in recent communal violence in Papua New Guinea.

item.title: Touring the Israeli Occupation: Young U.S. Jews Get an Unflinching View
item.description: Birthright Israel, which takes young Jews to Israel, has been criticized for ignoring the Palestinians. A Times reporter joins an alternative tour set up by J Street, a liberal lobbying group.
item.dc:creator: David M. Halbfinger
item.media:credit: Ilia Yefimovich for The New York Times
item.media:description: The students toured what were once Hebron’s main market streets, now a graveyard of abandoned storefronts and apartments.

item.title: Boris Johnson, France Télécom, Kyriakos Mitsotakis: Your Wednesday Briefing
item.description: Here’s what you need to know.
item.dc:creator: Melina Delkic

item.title: U.S.-British Relationship Sounding More Testy Than ‘Special’
item.description: President Trump’s harsh words for a British ambassador and for the prime minister have some wondering what a post-Brexit Britain can really count on from its longtime ally.
item.dc:creator: Steven Erlanger and Stephen Castle
item.media:description: Britain’s likely new prime minister, Boris Johnson, at a debate on Tuesday.

item.title: Iran Nuclear Deal Under New Threat as Europeans Consider Complaint
item.description: Three countries called on Iran to return to full compliance “without delay” and moved closer to a formal complaint, which could collapse the accord.
item.dc:creator: Rick Gladstone
item.media:description: Iran’s Natanz nuclear facility in 2007.

item.title: Jeffrey Epstein, Twitter, Wimbledon: Your Tuesday Evening Briefing
item.description: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
item.dc:creator: Remy Tumin and Hiroko Masuike

item.title: U.K. Parliament Backs Same-Sex Marriage and Abortion Rights in Northern Ireland
item.description: The votes set the stage for changes that would liberalize laws in Northern Ireland and drag the region into line with the rest of the United Kingdom.
item.dc:creator: Benjamin Mueller
item.category: Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships
item.media:description: Protesters calling for a change in Northern Ireland’s abortion law walking near Parliament in London.
